_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: State of Illinois, Fertilizer Law, Subpart A, Anhydrous Ammonia
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Administrative controls(Operation procedures) in place. Equiptment controls in place; remote manual shut-off valves & in-line excess flow automatic shut-down valves & load-out riser breakaway systems.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage Tanks, piping, pumps, and equiptment

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility: Shipman ElevatorCo. Carlinville Branch
Contact: Dean Allen
Phone: 618-729-9009

1. Facility Policy.

The owners, management and employees of Shipman Elevator Co. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, macoupin county ESDA, and/ or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the enviroment.

2. Facility Information.

The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is recieved, stored and distributed for direct application AS A NUTRIENT for crop production. The maximum quantity stored would be 420,000 pounds in storage tanks and nurse tanks.

3. Worst-case scenario and Alternate Release Scenario

a. The worst-case scenario would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank released as gas over a period of 10 minutes. The maximum quantity released would be 52,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the LARGEST storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by design standards and administrative controls. The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 parts per million, or ppm) is .84 miles.

b. The alternate release scenario, a 3 inch transfer hose is used as an alternate release scenario followed by the release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an automatic excess flow shut-down valve/valves intervenes or remote manual shut-off is closed and stops the flow of ammonia. The maximum quantity released would be 28,000 pounds. The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .80 miles. ( The most likely potential incident, would be a release from a break in a 1- inch transfer hose scenario follwed by the release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an automatic excess flow shut-down valve / valves intervenes or remote manual shut-off is closed and stops the flow of ammonia. the maximum

quantity released with this scenario would be 2901 pounds. The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .31 miles.

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility is in compliance with the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia, and the State of Illinois Fertilizer Law, Sub Part A, Anhydrous Ammonia. The OSHA standard is referenced in the RMP registration form, see section 8.3(b)

5. Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past 5 years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility: nor to our knowledge , has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage or enviromental damage.

6. Energency Action Report

The facility has:

a. A written action plan, in accordance with the OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38

b.Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

c. If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, the required response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all emergency response numbers.

   1. Within 15 minutes of determining the amount of the release to be over 100 pounds, the emergency coordinator will notify th National Response Center at 1-800-424-8802.

   2.Immediately (within one hour) after determining that the amount or release would be over 100 pounds, the Emergency Coordinator will notify the Illinois Enviromental Management Agency at 1-800-782-7860 (in state) or 271-782-7860 (out of state)
